msItem.author: Ps.-Seneca
msItem.title: De paupertate
msItem.rubric: Liber Senece De paupertate cuius est .v.m capitulum
msItem.incipit: Honesta quidem res est paupertas leta
msItem.bibl: Senecae opera. Supplementum, ed. F. Haase (Teubner, 1902), 56–9.

msItem.author: Ps.-Seneca
msItem.title: De remediis fortuitorum
msItem.rubric: Liber de Remediis fortuitorum Senece ad Gallionem
msItem.incipit: Hunc librum composuit Seneca nobilissimus orator ad Galionem quedam amicum suum
Licet cunctorum peotarum carmina gremium tuum semper illustrent
msItem.explicit: quam domi sit ista felicitas rara &c. Amen. Explicit.
msItem.bibl: Senecae opera. Supplementum, ed. F. Haase (Teubner, 1902), 44–55.

msItem.author: Ps.-Seneca
msItem.title: De morum institutione
msItem.explicit: aliud ore pretendamus. Amen. Explicit opusculum. Amen
msItem.bibl: Senecae opera. Supplementum, ed. F. Haase (Teubner, 1902), 60–65.
msItem.note: Corresponding to the pr. ed. only as far as §132, ‘Qui nescit tacere, nescit et loqui’ at fol. 11r, line 3; continuing ‘namque inprobi menciuntur idem probi debent, dicere longa vita bonis optabilis est …’, like the 1502 edition of the Liber de moribus humane vite.

msItem.author: Seneca
msItem.title: De tranquillitate animi (Dialogi 9)
msItem.rubric: Incipit Liber Senece de tranquilitate anime ad Serenum
msItem.incipit: Inquirenti michi in me quedam vicia apparebant
msItem.explicit: nisi intenta et assidua cura circumeat animum labentem
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de Tranquillitate animi ad Serenum Annei Senece.
msItem.bibl: Dialogorum libri duodecim, ed. L. D. Reynolds, OCT (1977), pp. 207–38

msItem.author: Martin of Braga (Ps.-Seneca)
msItem.title: Formula uitae honestae
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber Senece de quatuor virtutibus
msItem.incipit: Quatuor virtutum species multorum sapientum sentenciis diffinite sunt
msItem.explicit: deficientem inpingat ignauiam. Amen. Explicit opusculum Amen.
msItem.bibl: Opera omnia, ed. Barlow (New Haven, 1950), pp. 237–50.

msItem.author: Seneca
msItem.title: De breuitate uitae (Dialogi 10)
msItem.rubric: Incipit Liber Senece de Breuitate vite
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber Senece de breuitate vite
msItem.bibl: Dialogorum libri duodecim, ed. L. D. Reynolds, OCT (1977), pp. 239–90

msItem.title: Excerpts from Seneca
msItem.rubric: Recollecte ex quam pluribus varijs et diversibus Senece libris oratoris excellentissimi Cliuis Anno .1466.o
msItem.incipit: Furencium certa indicia sunt Audax et minax, vultus tristis
msItem.explicit: cum actu lacrimas tuas miscuisti hac. Seneca ad helbiam matrem suam de consolatione. Amen.
msItem.note: 18th-century table of contents on front pastedown: 'Excerpta ex variis libris Senecae'. Headings within the text introduce excerpts and paraphrases; the first and last are ‘Hec Seneca de Ira ad nouatum’ (fol. 66r) and ‘Hec Seneca ad Helbiam matrem suam’ (fol. 71v).

supportDesc.support: Parchment for the outermost and innermost bifolium of each quire, otherwise paper; Watson states that the watermark is probably Briquet no. 5799 (cf. WZIS), used in Utrecht in 1462 and other places in the Low Countries in the 1460s.
supportDesc.foliation: 1–72 in 19th(?)-century ink; i and 73 in modern pencil
Former foliation ‘.94.’–‘.168.’, in 15th-century ink, suggests that the volume was originally the second of a pair.
supportDesc.collation: 1–6(12); catchwords survive throughout; medieval leaf signatures survive sporadically, including ‘aj’ (fol. 1r), ‘e6’ (fol. 54r), and ‘f6’ (fol. 66r), suggesting that – despite the medieval foliation – the present leaves formed a discrete volume from the beginning.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet usually for 27 lines (fol. 1 with 28–29 lines). Written above top line. Ruled space c. 130 73

decoDesc.decoNote: One six-line initial painted in mauve, with reserved designs, and flourishing in red ink (fol. 1r); four-line initials in plain red with brown flourishing; two-, three-, and four- line initials in red or gray-mauve, with brown flourishing, one with a human face (fol. 30v).

binding.p: Sewn on five bands and bound in 16th(?)-century red-brown morocco, the covers framed with a gilt roll tool, and fleurons on each corner; the spine densely gilt, with a title in gilt capitals, ‘SENE | OPUS | VARI’ in the edges of the leaves speckled with red and green. The foot of the spine with two printed paper labels, with the former (‘X. 1. | 4. 41.’) and present Bodleian shelfmarks. The Summary Catalogue compared the binding of MS. D'Orville 142.

history.provenance: ‘Deus assit’ in the upper margin of fols. 1r, 36r; 15th-century manicula and marginal notes (apparently mainly by the main scribe).

Jacques Philippe D’Orville (1696–1751), classical scholar. Listed in the catalogue of D'Orville's collection by C. J. Strackhoven (18th century, second half), MS. D'Orville 302, fol. 21r, without recording the source of acquisition.
By descent to his son, Jean D'Orville, b. 1734, and a grandson also named Jean D'Orville, who sold the collection to:
history.acquisition: Purchased from him by the Bodleian in 1804. Former Bodleian shelfmarks: Auct. X. 1. 4. 41 (cf. spine label).

recordHist.source: Summary description (March 2021) by Peter Kidd, edited by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Summary Catalogue. Summary Catalogue, Vol. 4, p. 71

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: A. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts in Oxford Libraries (1984), no. 439

revisionDesc.change: Revised description for Polonsky German digitization project.
